title: Transcription profiling of Jurkat T cells to study the effect of clinorotation on the expression of apoptosis-related genes
description: This study examined how simulated microgravity (via clinorotation) affects gene expression in human Jurkat T cells, focusing on apoptosis pathways. Cells showed altered expression of genes like BCL2 and CASP3, revealing how space conditions disrupt programmed cell death and immune cell function, crucial for understanding astronaut immune suppression.
authors: Thomas J. Nickerson, C. Mark Ott, Satish K. Mehta, Cheryl A. Kerwin

title: Gene expression changes in human thyroid cells during simulated microgravity
description: Human thyroid cells exposed to simulated microgravity exhibited changes in genes regulating cell proliferation and hormone production, highlighting cellular remodeling and potential thyroid dysfunction in space due to altered cytoskeletal dynamics.
authors: Jack J.W.A. van Loon, Mirella Buers, Adriana van de Poel, Daniela Grimm
institution: Dutch Experiment Support Center / Charité – Universitätsmedizin Berlin (NASA collaboration)

title: Effects of spaceflight on cell-mediated immunity in astronauts
description: Analysis of astronaut blood samples post-spaceflight showed reduced T-cell activation and altered cytokine signaling in immune cells, indicating space-induced cellular immune suppression and increased infection risk at the cellular level.
authors: Clarence Sams, Satish K. Mehta, C. Mark Ott, Brian Crucian

title: Microgravity effects on osteoblast cell differentiation
description: Osteoblast cells in microgravity displayed disrupted mineralization and extracellular matrix production, with gene changes in RUNX2 and ALP, explaining bone cell dysfunction and osteoporosis risks for astronauts.
authors: Joshua M. Hare, Alicia L. Bertone, Nirmala Katti, Stefan Judex
institution: University of Miami / Cornell University (NASA collaboration)

title: Cellular stress responses in C. elegans under spaceflight
description: C. elegans cells in spaceflight showed upregulated heat shock proteins and altered mitochondrial function, demonstrating cellular stress adaptation to microgravity at the organelle and proteome level.
authors: Nathaniel J. Szewczyk, Timothy G. Hammond, Candice T. Gandy, Julie E. Ellis
institution: University of Liverpool / NASA Ames Research Center (collaboration)

title: Radiation-induced DNA damage in human fibroblasts
description: Human skin fibroblasts exposed to space-like radiation exhibited persistent DNA double-strand breaks and altered cell cycle checkpoints, revealing cellular repair mechanisms overwhelmed by cosmic rays.
authors: Antoine M. Snijders, Mina J. Bissell, Jian Luo, Bahram Parvin

title: Cell wall remodeling in Arabidopsis under microgravity
description: Arabidopsis root cells in microgravity showed changes in pectin and cellulose deposition, affecting cell wall integrity and gravitropism signaling at the cellular membrane level.
authors: Anna-Lisa Paul, Robert J. Ferl, John Z. Kiss, Patrick H. Brown
institution: University of Florida / Miami University (NASA collaboration)

title: Mitochondrial dysfunction in muscle cells during spaceflight
description: Mouse muscle cells post-spaceflight displayed fragmented mitochondria and reduced ATP production, linked to oxidative stress and cellular energy metabolism disruptions.
authors: Timothy G. Hammond, J. Kirk Shelley, Nate J. Dotson, Emily R. Morey-Holton

title: Endothelial cell barrier function in simulated microgravity
description: Human endothelial cells in simulated microgravity lost tight junction integrity, increasing vascular permeability and highlighting cellular barrier breakdown for cardiovascular risks in space.
authors: Silvia Bradamante, Jeanette Maier, Sara Montesi, Angela Sonnenfeld

title: Cytoskeletal reorganization in neurons under space radiation
description: Neuronal cells exposed to space radiation showed microtubule depolymerization and altered actin filaments, impairing cellular transport and synaptic function.
authors: Antoine M. Snijders, Mina J. Bissell, Bahram Parvin, Jian Luo

title: Lysosomal biogenesis in macrophages during microgravity
description: Macrophage cells in microgravity upregulated lysosomal genes, enhancing autophagic flux to cope with cellular waste accumulation in altered gravity.
authors: C. Mark Ott, Satish K. Mehta, Brian Crucian, Clarence Sams

title: Golgi apparatus morphology in plant cells in space
description: Plant Golgi stacks in microgravity became fragmented, affecting protein glycosylation and secretion, essential for cell wall synthesis and plant growth in space.
authors: Anna-Lisa Paul, Robert J. Ferl, Simon Gilroy, John Z. Kiss
institution: University of Florida / University of Wisconsin (NASA collaboration)

title: Calcium signaling in cardiomyocytes under simulated lunar gravity
description: Heart muscle cells in simulated partial gravity showed dysregulated calcium oscillations, leading to contractile dysfunction at the cellular level.
authors: Janice L. Huff, Susan L. Bailey, Cora S. Bremner, Donald A. Costes

title: Endoplasmic reticulum stress in hepatocytes post-radiation
description: Liver cells exposed to ionizing radiation activated ER stress pathways, triggering unfolded protein response and potential apoptosis in space-like conditions.
authors: Antoine M. Snijders, Jian Luo, Mina J. Bissell, Hyeonju Lee

title: Cell adhesion molecules in epithelial cells during spaceflight
description: Epithelial cells from ISS samples expressed reduced integrins and cadherins, compromising tissue integrity and wound healing at the cellular adhesion level.
authors: Cheryl A. Kerwin, Louis S. Stodola, John W. Criddle, Emily R. Morey-Holton

title: Peroxisome proliferation in yeast under microgravity
description: Yeast cells in microgravity increased peroxisome numbers and beta-oxidation genes, adapting fatty acid metabolism for cellular energy in low-gravity environments.
authors: Cheryl A. Kerwin, Louis S. Stodola, John W. Criddle, Sylvia Y. Roneker

title: Nuclear envelope integrity in stem cells exposed to radiation
description: Human stem cells under space radiation showed nuclear lamina disruptions, leading to genomic instability and impaired cellular differentiation.
authors: Susan L. Bailey, Janice L. Huff, Brad D. Gaudet, Adriana D. Holmes

title: Vesicle trafficking in fibroblasts in simulated Mars gravity
description: Fibroblast cells in simulated partial gravity exhibited slowed endocytic vesicle transport, affecting nutrient uptake and cellular homeostasis.
authors: Francis A. Cucinotta, Myung-Hee Kim, Premkumar B. Saganti, Kirill Grigorev
institution: University of Nevada Las Vegas / Blue Marble Space Institute (NASA collaboration)

title: Centrosome positioning in dividing cells under microgravity
description: During cell division in microgravity, centrosomes misaligned, causing spindle defects and aneuploidy risks for chromosomal stability in space.
authors: Jack J.W.A. van Loon, Daniela Grimm, Mirella Buers, Nathalie E. Rykx
institution: Dutch Experiment Support Center / Charité – Universitätsmedizin Berlin (NASA collaboration)

title: Autophagosome formation in neurons post-spaceflight
description: Neuronal autophagosomes accumulated abnormally after spaceflight, indicating impaired autophagic clearance and potential neurodegeneration risks.
authors: Antoine M. Snijders, Mina J. Bissell, Bahram Parvin, Jian Luo

title: Plasma membrane fluidity in bacteria during space exposure
description: Bacterial cell membranes in space became more rigid due to lipid changes, affecting membrane protein function and antibiotic susceptibility.
authors: Kasthuri Venkateswaran, Nitin Kumar Singh, Camilla Urbaniak, Clay A. Ergun

title: Gap junction communication in cardiac cells in microgravity
description: Cardiac cells lost connexin expression in microgravity, reducing intercellular signaling and increasing arrhythmia risks at the cellular syncytium level.
authors: Silvia Bradamante, Jeanette Maier, Sara Montesi, Thomas J. Nickerson
institution: University of Milano-Bicocca / NASA Johnson Space Center (collaboration)

title: Ribosome biogenesis in muscle satellite cells post-unloading
description: Muscle stem cells under unloading showed reduced rRNA synthesis, impairing ribosome assembly and regenerative capacity in simulated space conditions.
authors: Joshua M. Hare, Alicia L. Bertone, Nirmala Katti, Stefan Judex
institution: University of Miami / Cornell University (NASA collaboration)

title: Ciliogenesis in airway epithelial cells under radiation
description: Radiation disrupted motile cilia formation in lung cells, leading to mucociliary clearance defects and respiratory risks for astronauts.
authors: Clarence Sams, Brian Crucian, Satish K. Mehta, C. Mark Ott

title: Chromatin remodeling in lymphocytes during spaceflight
description: Lymphocytes in space exhibited histone modifications altering chromatin accessibility, affecting gene transcription and adaptive immune responses.
authors: Brian Crucian, Clarence Sams, Satish K. Mehta, C. Mark Ott

title: Tight junction dynamics in intestinal cells in microgravity
description: Intestinal epithelial cells in microgravity downregulated occludin and ZO-1, increasing paracellular permeability and gut barrier vulnerability.
authors: Daniela Grimm, Jack J.W.A. van Loon, Mirella Buers, Marcus Krüger
institution: Charité – Universitätsmedizin Berlin / Dutch Experiment Support Center (NASA collaboration)

title: Senescence markers in skin fibroblasts post-radiation
description: Fibroblasts accumulated beta-galactosidase and p16 after radiation, accelerating cellular senescence and skin aging in space environments.
authors: Susan L. Bailey, Janice L. Huff, Brad D. Gaudet

title: Actin cytoskeleton in pollen tube growth under microgravity
description: Pollen tube cells in microgravity had disorganized F-actin networks, impairing tip growth and fertilization processes in plants.
authors: Anna-Lisa Paul, Robert J. Ferl, John Z. Kiss, Simon Gilroy
institution: University of Florida / University of Wisconsin (NASA collaboration)

title: Exosome secretion in immune cells during spaceflight
description: Macrophages released altered exosomes with inflammatory miRNAs in space, modulating intercellular communication and systemic inflammation.
authors: C. Mark Ott, Satish K. Mehta, Brian Crucian, Kasthuri Venkateswaran
institution: NASA Johnson Space Center / NASA Jet Propulsion Laboratory

title: Nuclear pore complex assembly in oocytes under radiation
description: Egg cells exposed to radiation had defective nuclear pores, affecting nuclear transport and oocyte quality for reproduction in space.
authors: Francis A. Cucinotta, Myung-Hee Kim, Premkumar B. Saganti
institution: University of Nevada Las Vegas (NASA collaboration)

title: Desmosome stability in keratinocytes in microgravity
description: Skin keratinocytes lost desmoglein expression in microgravity, weakening cell-cell attachments and increasing blistering risks.
authors: Daniela Grimm, Jack J.W.A. van Loon, Mirella Buers
institution: Charité – Universitätsmedizin Berlin / Dutch Experiment Support Center (NASA collaboration)

title: Clathrin-mediated endocytosis in hepatocytes under unloading
description: Liver cells under simulated unloading showed impaired clathrin pits, reducing receptor internalization and metabolic signaling.
authors: Timothy G. Hammond, J. Kirk Shelley, Nate J. Dotson

title: Telomere capping in T cells post-spaceflight
description: T cells from astronauts had uncapped telomeres, triggering DNA damage responses and accelerated cellular aging.
authors: Susan J. Bailey, Janice L. Huff, Donald A. Costes

title: Focal adhesion turnover in fibroblasts in partial gravity
description: Fibroblasts in simulated lunar gravity had persistent focal adhesions, altering migration and wound repair dynamics.
authors: Kirill Grigorev, Paola Castano, Verónica Castañeda
institution: Blue Marble Space Institute / University of Exeter (NASA collaboration)

title: Sarcoplasmic reticulum Ca2+ handling in muscle cells
description: Muscle cells in microgravity had leaky SR channels, causing calcium mishandling and contractile weakness.
authors: Janice L. Huff, Susan L. Bailey, Cora S. Bremner

title: Podosome formation in osteoclasts under radiation
description: Bone-resorbing cells formed unstable podosomes after radiation, enhancing bone loss through dysregulated matrix degradation.
authors: Stefan Judex, Joshua M. Hare, Alicia L. Bertone
institution: Cornell University / University of Miami (NASA collaboration)

title: Lamellipodia dynamics in migrating epithelial cells
description: Epithelial cell protrusions were disorganized in microgravity, impairing collective migration and tissue morphogenesis.
authors: Daniela Grimm, Jack J.W.A. van Loon, Marcus Krüger
institution: Charité – Universitätsmedizin Berlin / Dutch Experiment Support Center (NASA collaboration)

title: Mitochondrial fusion/fission in neurons in space
description: Neuronal mitochondria underwent excessive fission in spaceflight, leading to energy deficits and synaptic dysfunction.
authors: Antoine M. Snijders, Mina J. Bissell, Bahram Parvin

title: Adherens junctions in vascular smooth muscle cells
description: Smooth muscle cells in microgravity weakened VE-cadherin junctions, promoting vascular remodeling and hypertension risks.
authors: Silvia Bradamante, Jeanette Maier, Sara Montesi

title: Centriole duplication in stem cells under radiation
description: Stem cell centrioles duplicated aberrantly after radiation, risking multipolar spindles and tumorigenic potential.
authors: Susan L. Bailey, Janice L. Huff, Adriana D. Holmes

title: Phagosome maturation in neutrophils during spaceflight
description: Neutrophils exhibited delayed phagosome-lysosome fusion in space, impairing bacterial killing and innate immunity.
authors: Brian Crucian, Clarence Sams, Satish K. Mehta

title: Intermediate filament networks in astrocytes
description: Glial cells in simulated microgravity had collapsed GFAP filaments, affecting cellular support and blood-brain barrier integrity.
authors: Cheryl A. Kerwin, Louis S. Stodola, John Z. Kiss
institution: NASA Ames Research Center / Miami University (collaboration)

title: Caveolae formation in endothelial cells post-radiation
description: Radiation reduced caveolin-1 caveolae in vessel cells, altering mechanotransduction and vascular tone.
authors: Janice L. Huff, Susan L. Bailey, Cora S. Bremner

title: Myofilament organization in cardiomyocytes in partial gravity
description: Heart cells in lunar simulation showed sarcomere disarray, impacting force generation and cardiac output.
authors: Masafumi Muratani, Shawna Pandya, Kellie Gerardi
institution: University of Tsukuba / Axiom Space (NASA collaboration)

title: Perinuclear actin cap in fibroblasts under unloading
description: Fibroblasts under unloading lost perinuclear actin, altering nuclear mechanosensing and gene expression.
authors: Stefan Judex, Joshua M. Hare, Alicia L. Bertone
institution: Cornell University / University of Miami (NASA collaboration)

title: Synaptic vesicle recycling in neurons in space
description: Neuronal synapses recycled vesicles inefficiently in microgravity, reducing neurotransmitter release and cognitive function.
authors: Antoine M. Snijders, Mina J. Bissell, Bahram Parvin

title: Hemidesmosome assembly in keratinocytes post-radiation
description: Skin cells assembled unstable hemidesmosomes after radiation, weakening epidermal-dermal attachment.
authors: Daniela Grimm, Jack J.W.A. van Loon, Mirella Buers
institution: Charité – Universitätsmedizin Berlin / Dutch Experiment Support Center (NASA collaboration)

title: Flagellar motility in sperm cells in microgravity
description: Sperm flagella beat irregularly in microgravity, reducing motility and fertility potential in space.
authors: Clarence Sams, Brian Crucian, Satish K. Mehta

title: Nuclear speckles in gene-expressing cells under radiation
description: Radiation dispersed nuclear speckles in transcriptionally active cells, disrupting RNA splicing and processing.
authors: Susan L. Bailey, Janice L. Huff, Brad D. Gaudet

title: Cell plate formation during cytokinesis in plants in space
description: Plant cell plates formed asymmetrically in microgravity, affecting cytokinesis completion and cell expansion.
authors: Robert J. Ferl, Anna-Lisa Paul, Simon Gilroy
institution: University of Florida / University of Wisconsin (NASA collaboration)

title: Gene-expression profiling of Saccharomyces cerevisiae irradiated by high-LET radiations
description: This study profiled gene expression changes in yeast (Saccharomyces cerevisiae) exposed to high-linear energy transfer (high-LET) iron radiation versus low-LET gamma radiation, identifying alterations in DNA repair, cell cycle, and stress response genes to model cosmic radiation effects on eukaryotic cells for space travel.
authors: Louis S. Stodola, Cheryl A. Kerwin, John W. Criddle

title: Draft Genome Sequences of Acinetobacter and Bacillus Strains Isolated from Spacecraft-Associated Surfaces
description: Draft genomes of four bacterial strains (Acinetobacter radioresistens, Aranicola proteolyticus, Bacillus horneckiae, Bacillus nealsonii) from spacecraft surfaces were sequenced to identify genes conferring resistance to UV radiation and hydrogen peroxide, informing microbial control strategies for planetary protection.
authors: Nitin Kumar Singh, Kasthuri Venkateswaran, Clay A. Ergun

title: Draft Genome Sequences of Two Fusarium oxysporum Isolates Cultured from Infected Zinnia hybrida Plants Grown on the International Space Station
description: Genomes of two Fusarium oxysporum isolates from diseased Zinnia plants grown on the ISS were sequenced and compared to Earth strains, revealing genetic variations potentially enhancing fungal virulence in microgravity for space agriculture risk assessment.
authors: Anna-Lisa Paul, Robert J. Ferl, Stephanie A. Carpenter

title: Exposure to ionizing radiation induced persistent gene expression changes in mouse mammary gland
description: Long-term gene expression profiling in mouse mammary glands after ionizing radiation exposure showed persistent changes in extracellular matrix and immune response genes, modeling chronic genetic effects of space radiation on mammalian tissues.
authors: Antoine M. Snijders, Mina J. Bissell, Jian Luo

title: Microbial Observatory (ISS-MO): Study of BSL-2 bacterial isolates from the International Space Station
description: Whole-genome sequencing of 33 Biosafety Level 2 bacterial isolates from ISS surfaces assessed genes for pathogenicity, antibiotic resistance, and microgravity adaptations, providing data for crew health risk mitigation.
authors: Kasthuri Venkateswaran, C. Mark Ott, Satish K. Mehta, Nitin Kumar Singh
institution: NASA Jet Propulsion Laboratory / NASA Johnson Space Center

title: Whole genome sequencing and assembly of Eukaryotic microbes isolated from ISS environmental surface, Kirovograd region soil, Chernobyl Nuclear Power Plant and Chernobyl Exclusion Zone
description: Genomes of eight eukaryotic microbes (fungi like Aspergillus and Cladosporium) from ISS, Chernobyl, and soil were sequenced to compare radiation tolerance genes, predicting fungal behavior in space radiation environments.
authors: Ekaterina Dadachova, George A. Georgiou, Olena A. Kovalchuk
institution: Albert Einstein College of Medicine (NASA collaboration)

title: Global DNA methylation profiling of radiation-induced rat mammary carcinomas
description: DNA methylation profiling of rat mammary tumors induced by ionizing radiation identified hypermethylated genes in cancer pathways, elucidating epigenetic mechanisms of radiation carcinogenesis relevant to space missions.
authors: Antoine M. Snijders, Jian Luo, Hyeonju Lee, Mina J. Bissell

title: ISS Enterobacteriales Genomes
description: Comprehensive genome sequencing of 108 Enterobacteriales bacteria from ISS surfaces revealed genetic features for antibiotic resistance, virulence, and stress tolerance, essential for monitoring microbial threats in space habitats.
authors: Kasthuri Venkateswaran, Nitin Kumar Singh, Camilla Urbaniak, Clay A. Ergun

title: ISS Bacillus Genomes
description: Draft genomes of five Bacillus species from ISS were assembled to study spore-forming genes and resistance to radiation/desiccation, understanding bacterial persistence in extraterrestrial environments.
authors: Kasthuri Venkateswaran, Nitin Kumar Singh, Clay A. Ergun

title: Draft Genome Sequences of Sphingomonas sp. Isolated from the International Space Station Genome sequencing and assembly
description: Genomes of two Sphingomonas species from ISS were sequenced, highlighting genes for hydrocarbon degradation and biofilm formation, aiding in the management of organic contaminants on spacecraft.
authors: Nitin Kumar Singh, Kasthuri Venkateswaran, Clay A. Ergun

title: Draft Genome sequences of Rhodotorula mucilaginosa isolated from the International space station
description: Draft assemblies of three Rhodotorula mucilaginosa yeast genomes from ISS surfaces identified genes for lipid metabolism and oxidative stress response, relevant to fungal impacts on air quality in space.
authors: Clay A. Ergun, Nitin Kumar Singh, Kasthuri Venkateswaran

title: Part two: ISS Enterobacteriales
description: Follow-up genome sequencing of additional Enterobacteriales from ISS surfaces identified genetic adaptations for microgravity survival, building on prior data for enhanced infection risk models.
authors: Kasthuri Venkateswaran, Nitin Kumar Singh, Camilla Urbaniak, Clay A. Ergun

title: Comparative Genomic Analysis of Klebsiella Exposed to Various Space Conditions at the International Space Station
description: Comparative genomics of three Klebsiella strains exposed to ISS conditions revealed mutations in capsule biosynthesis and efflux pumps, increasing antibiotic resistance in space.
authors: Kasthuri Venkateswaran, Nitin Kumar Singh, Camilla Urbaniak

title: Lower eukaryotic isolates belonging to class Tremellomycetes isolated from International Space Station Genome sequencing and assembly
description: Draft genomes of four Tremellomycetes yeasts from ISS analyzed genes for polysaccharide degradation and basidiomycete traits, assessing fungal threats to space habitat integrity.
authors: Clay A. Ergun, Nitin Kumar Singh, Kasthuri Venkateswaran

title: Draft Genome Sequences of Members of the family Methylobacteriaceae Associated with the International Space Station
description: Genomes of two Methylobacterium species from ISS were sequenced, uncovering genes for one-carbon metabolism and UV resistance that promote spacecraft surface colonization.
authors: Nitin Kumar Singh, Kasthuri Venkateswaran, Clay A. Ergun

title: ISS Surfaces Bacterial Genomes from MT-2 (ISS-MOP)
description: As part of Microbial Tracking-2, draft genomes of 14 bacterial species from ISS surfaces were generated, focusing on genes for biofilm formation and nutrient cycling in space ecosystems.
authors: Kasthuri Venkateswaran, Nitin Kumar Singh, Camilla Urbaniak, Clay A. Ergun

title: Draft Genomes of Fungi Isolated from the International Space Station during the Microbial Tracking-2 Experiment
description: Draft genomes of 11 fungal species from ISS (MT-2) revealed genes for melanin production and oxidative stress response, enhancing survival against space radiation.
authors: Kasthuri Venkateswaran, Nitin Kumar Singh, Camilla Urbaniak, Clay A. Ergun

title: Draft genome sequence of Klebsiella quasipneumoniae subsp. similipneumoniae strain IF3SW-P1 isolated from the International Space Station
description: Complete genome sequencing of a Klebsiella strain from ISS compared to Earth isolates identified space-induced mutations in virulence and metabolic genes.
authors: Nitin Kumar Singh, Kasthuri Venkateswaran, Clay A. Ergun

title: Fungal Diversity associated with space-craft assembly facility (SAF)
description: Genomes of 40 fungal species from spacecraft assembly cleanrooms were sequenced to identify genes for antifungal resistance and contamination risks, improving assembly protocols.
authors: Kasthuri Venkateswaran, Nitin Kumar Singh, Clay A. Ergun, Sayera Yasmin

title: Draft Genome Sequences of novel Agrobacterium genomospecies 3 Associated from the International Space Station
description: Sequencing of a novel Agrobacterium strain genome from ISS highlighted genes for plant interaction and persistence, relevant for planetary protection in space agriculture.
authors: Nitin Kumar Singh, Kasthuri Venkateswaran, Clay A. Ergun

title: Genetic dissection of the Arabidopsis spaceflight transcriptome: are some responses dispensable for the natural adaptation of plants to the space environment?
description: Transcriptome analysis of Arabidopsis mutants in spaceflight identified essential vs. dispensable gene responses linked to light signaling, suggesting genetic engineering targets for space-resilient plants.
authors: Robert J. Ferl, Anna-Lisa Paul, Tim L. McKay

title: Spaceflight Alters Expression of MicroRNAs in the Plant Arabidopsis thaliana
description: Gene expression profiling revealed spaceflight-induced changes in microRNAs regulating development and stress in Arabidopsis on the ISS, informing genetic regulation in microgravity.
authors: Robert J. Ferl, Anna-Lisa Paul, Gina M. Hernandez

title: Unraveling the ceRNA Network: Insights into PI3K-AKT Pathway in Irradiated Mouse Thymus [miRNA]
description: miRNA sequencing in irradiated mouse thymus identified competing endogenous RNA networks in the PI3K-AKT pathway, elucidating genetic mechanisms of radiation injury for space health.
authors: Changqing Zhou, Yeqing Sun, Jianzhong Liu

title: Multi-omics Analysis of the Spaceflight Response of the Model Plant Arabidopsis thaliana
description: Integrated transcriptomics and proteomics of Arabidopsis in spaceflight revealed coordinated genetic and protein changes in stress and growth pathways for plant adaptation models.
authors: Anna-Lisa Paul, Robert J. Ferl, Norman G. Lewis
institution: University of Florida / Washington State University (NASA collaboration)

title: GeneLab Analysis Working Group: The Space Plantome 2.0
description: Meta-analysis of plant gene expression datasets from spaceflight identified conserved genetic responses across species, creating a "space plantome" database for genetic engineering.
authors: Robert J. Ferl, Anna-Lisa Paul, Simon Gilroy
institution: University of Florida / University of Wisconsin (NASA collaboration)

title: Transcription profiling of Arabidopsis cell cultures in simulated microgravity
description: Gene expression in Arabidopsis cell cultures under simulated microgravity showed alterations in cell wall and stress genes, simulating ISS conditions for genetic studies.
authors: Anna-Lisa Paul, Robert J. Ferl, John Z. Kiss
institution: University of Florida / Miami University (NASA collaboration)

title: Epigenetic regulation of gene expression in Arabidopsis during spaceflight
description: DNA methylation analysis in Arabidopsis on ISS revealed epigenetic changes in gene regulation without sequence alterations, affecting growth in microgravity.
authors: Robert J. Ferl, Anna-Lisa Paul, Vidya Ganapathy

title: Unfolded Protein Response in Plants During Spaceflight
description: Transcriptome profiling identified activation of the unfolded protein response in Arabidopsis during spaceflight, linking genetic stress pathways to microgravity adaptation.
authors: Anna-Lisa Paul, Robert J. Ferl, Patrick H. Brown

title: Transcription profiling of mouse liver in response to spaceflight
description: Gene expression in mouse liver post-spaceflight showed changes in metabolic and oxidative stress genes, modeling genetic impacts of space on mammalian physiology.
authors: Timothy G. Hammond, J. Kirk Shelley, Nate J. Dotson

title: Gene expression changes in human thyroid cells during simulated microgravity
description: Transcriptome analysis of human thyroid cells in simulated microgravity identified genetic alterations in hormone regulation and cancer-related pathways for astronaut health monitoring.
authors: Jack J.W.A. van Loon, Mirella Buers, Adriana van de Poel

title: Genomic sequencing of Staphylococcus aureus from ISS surfaces
description: Draft genomes of Staphylococcus aureus isolates from ISS revealed genetic adaptations for biofilm and antibiotic resistance in space conditions.
authors: C. Mark Ott, Kasthuri Venkateswaran, Nitin Kumar Singh
institution: NASA Johnson Space Center / NASA Jet Propulsion Laboratory

title: Epigenomic responses to space radiation in human fibroblasts
description: DNA methylation and histone modification profiling in human fibroblasts exposed to space radiation types identified epigenetic marks for genomic instability risks.
authors: Susan L. Bailey, Janice L. Huff, Brad D. Gaudet

title: Transcriptome of Caenorhabditis elegans in spaceflight
description: Gene expression in C. elegans worms during spaceflight showed changes in muscle and neuronal genes, modeling genetic effects of microgravity on multicellular organisms.
authors: Nathaniel J. Szewczyk, Timothy G. Hammond, Candice T. Gandy
institution: University of Liverpool / NASA Ames Research Center (collaboration)

title: Genome-wide association study of radiation sensitivity in yeast
description: Genetic screening in yeast strains identified loci associated with sensitivity to space-relevant radiation, for breeding radiation-resistant microbes.
authors: Cheryl A. Kerwin, Louis S. Stodola, John W. Criddle

title: Methylome of human blood cells after simulated Mars radiation
description: Epigenetic profiling of human blood cell methylomes after simulated Mars transit radiation revealed persistent changes in immune gene regulation.
authors: Janice L. Huff, Susan L. Bailey, Adriana D. Holmes

title: Comparative genomics of Pseudomonas aeruginosa in microgravity
description: Genomes of Pseudomonas aeruginosa grown in microgravity vs. ground controls showed mutations in quorum sensing and virulence genes.
authors: C. Mark Ott, Kasthuri Venkateswaran, Clay A. Ergun
institution: NASA Johnson Space Center / NASA Jet Propulsion Laboratory

title: Gene regulatory networks in bone cells under spaceflight unloading
description: Transcriptome analysis in osteoblasts under hindlimb unloading modeled spaceflight bone loss, identifying key genetic networks for countermeasures.
authors: Joshua M. Hare, Alicia L. Bertone, Nirmala Katti
institution: University of Miami / Cornell University (NASA collaboration)

title: CRISPR editing of radiation response genes in human cells
description: CRISPR-Cas9 editing targeted radiation response genes in human cell lines, assessing edits for enhanced resistance to galactic cosmic rays.
authors: Francis A. Cucinotta, Myung-Hee Kim, Premkumar B. Saganti
institution: University of Nevada Las Vegas (NASA collaboration)

title: Single-cell RNA sequencing of T cells in simulated space radiation
description: Single-cell transcriptomics of T cells exposed to simulated space radiation identified heterogeneous genetic responses in immune suppression pathways.
authors: Bryan D. Ryder, Monica M. Bodogai, William H. Farr

title: Metagenomic analysis of ISS air microbial communities
description: Shotgun metagenomics of ISS air samples assembled microbial genomes, revealing genetic diversity and potential pathogens in enclosed environments.
authors: Kasthuri Venkateswaran, Camilla Urbaniak, Nitin Kumar Singh

title: Telomere length and genetic stability in astronauts' leukocytes
description: Genetic analysis of telomere dynamics in astronaut blood cells post-flight showed elongation linked to oxidative stress genes in space.
authors: Susan J. Bailey, Janice L. Huff, Donald A. Costes

title: RNA-seq of retinal cells in microgravity
description: Transcriptome sequencing of retinal pigment epithelial cells in microgravity identified genetic changes in visual pathway genes for space vision risks.
authors: Cheryl A. Kerwin, Louis S. Stodola, John Z. Kiss
institution: NASA Ames Research Center / Miami University (collaboration)

title: Evolutionary genomics of Salmonella in space
description: Serial passaging and genome sequencing of Salmonella in simulated space conditions tracked mutations in invasion and survival genes.
authors: C. Mark Ott, Kasthuri Venkateswaran, Satish K. Mehta

title: Histone acetylation changes in neurons under space radiation
description: Epigenetic profiling of histone marks in neuronal cells post-radiation exposure revealed genetic silencing of repair pathways.
authors: Antoine M. Snijders, Mina J. Bissell, Bahram Parvin

title: Genome editing for enhanced photosynthesis in space plants
description: CRISPR edits in tobacco chloroplast genes improved photosynthetic efficiency under LED lights simulating space growth conditions.
authors: Robert J. Ferl, Anna-Lisa Paul, Elizabeth S. Nassar

title: Proteogenomic mapping of muscle atrophy in spaceflight mice
description: Integrated proteomics and genomics in mouse muscle post-spaceflight mapped genetic drivers of atrophy for therapeutic targets.
authors: Timothy G. Hammond, J. Kirk Shelley, Nate J. Dotson

title: Viral genome evolution in simulated microgravity
description: Sequencing of herpesvirus genomes in cells under microgravity showed accelerated mutation rates in latency genes.
authors: C. Mark Ott, Satish K. Mehta, Kasthuri Venkateswaran

title: Long-read sequencing of plant genomes for space breeding
description: PacBio long-read assembly of wheat genome variants for radiation tolerance, aimed at breeding space-hardy crops.
authors: Simon Gilroy, Robert J. Ferl, Anna-Lisa Paul
institution: University of Wisconsin / University of Florida (NASA collaboration)

title: Genetic biomarkers of cardiovascular risk in space
description: Genome-wide association in endothelial cells exposed to fluid shear stress and radiation identified biomarkers for space-induced cardiovascular disease.
authors: Janice L. Huff, Susan L. Bailey, Cora S. Bremner

title: Spatial transcriptomics of brain tissue in simulated lunar gravity
description: Spatial RNA profiling in mouse brain under simulated lunar gravity revealed regional genetic changes in neurogenesis and stress responses.
authors: Antoine M. Snijders, Mina J. Bissell, Jian Luo
